I understand that "hierarchical, modular, and formalized" are
sometimes vie=
wed as advantages for Grammatical Encoding (a similar
argument is also made=
 for L-systems, which is also grammatical). 
While these are clearly proper=
ties you want in a programming language,
are these really good things for a=
 genetic encoding?  The challenge
with encodings is not only for them to th=
eoretically express all
possible procedures, but also to induce a nicely co=
upled (smooth)
search space.  It seems that the space induced by a strictly=
 modular
and hierarchical encodings is unlikely to be smooth, leading to
br=
ittleness.  You can have things like a massive new module being
doubled in =
one shot (which would usually be a mess, like being born
with two heads) or=
 a change at one level of the hierarchy breaking the
rest of it entirely.  =


I am not dismissing GE, but I would want to hear an argument
supporting i=
t more from the encoding and search spaces side rather
than from the formal=
 languages side.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jean-Baptiste Mouret / =
Mandor
<mandor@...> wrote:
>
> From: "shaflidason" <styrmis@...>
> > <shane=
mcdonaldryan@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Has anyone ever compared the performance =
of grammatical evolution to
> > > neuro evolution? Perhaps on the standard =
problems
pole-balancing, xor.
> > > 
> > > It seems quite promising and I c=
an post my results when they are
done.
> > > But I wanted to see if anyone =
else has looked into it before I do.
> > > I've invested quite a bit of ene=
ry in NE but GE looks very
promising,
> > > and I like the fact that it pro=
duces actual code rather than a black
> > > box. Which makes it more approp=
riate for some domains. ie commercial
> > > video games.
> 
> I did some co=
mparaisons of NEAT with regards to our attribute grammar
> based encoding (=
this is not grammatical evolution but it's related). I
> used a pole-balanc=
ing task and a task in which a multi-dof robotic arm
> had to move to defin=
ed positions. Our system performed a bit better
> than NEAT on these tasks =
but NEAT could probably be tweaked
> more. While I'm very happy with the th=
eoritical features of the
> encodings (it's hierarchical, modular and forma=
lized), more benchmarks
> will be needed to draw any final conclusion about=
 the "efficiency"
> (btw, Ken previously highlighted the problems with benc=
hmarks such as
> those).
> 
> See : http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s12065-008-00=
15-7
> 
> Best regards,
